title: Ep #146 From College to Career: Coaching Students Toward Success with Jennifer Koller
author: Vintage Contessa & Times Past

key_facts: Jennifer Kohler is a trained coach with experience in leadership and career coaching from Rice University.
She works primarily with international students applying to US universities, especially those from Europe.
She uses assessments like EQI and Science to help students identify skills, aptitudes, and interests.
The assessment process includes online questionnaires that generate reports on potential career paths.
Students often discover careers they were unaware of through these assessments.
She emphasizes the importance of self-discovery during the first year of college planning.
She helps students explore internships, research projects, and summer activities to build their profiles.
Trust is a key component in her relationship with students and families.
She has worked with transfer students from European countries who did not pass their first year.
Many European educational systems select students for university tracks at a younger age.
US universities do not have a standardized admissions process; each evaluates applicants holistically.
MIT admits only 110 international undergraduate students annually.
European students often apply to fewer universities compared to US students.
In the UK, admission to top universities like Cambridge is based heavily on predicted grades.
US students can apply to up to 20 schools via the Common App, increasing competition.
Some students transfer after starting at a university due to academic or personal reasons.
Students may switch majors or pathways even after being admitted to a university.
Jennifer Kohler advises families to start planning early, ideally in middle school.
She encourages students to pursue what they love and connect it to meaningful experiences.
She supports students in writing essays by helping them articulate their passions clearly.
key_opinions: The most important factor in college admissions is strong academic performance.
Students should focus on discovering their true interests rather than chasing prestige.
It's better to attend a university where you can thrive than one that seems prestigious but isn't a good fit.
Parents should trust their childs instincts over peer pressure or societal expectations.
Coaching is most effective when students feel heard and respected, not led.
A students passion matters more than a perfect resume if its authentic and well-communicated.
The idea that every student must volunteer everywhere to get into college is a myth.
Students dont need to follow a rigid timelinesome benefit from taking breaks between experiences.
Universities are increasingly open to non-traditional paths and diverse backgrounds.
The Southern US is becoming a more competitive and attractive region for higher education.
Community college can be a valid and strategic pathway to top universities.
Students should choose schools where their strengths will be recognized and nurtured.
The belief that only elite schools lead to success is outdated and misleading.
Students should not be pressured to conform to family expectations if it doesnt align with their identity.
Building confidence through overcoming failure is more valuable than avoiding mistakes.
key_datapoints: MIT admits 110 international undergraduate students per year.
Over 50% of MITs graduate students are international.
UK universities typically require IB scores of 4045 out of 45 for top institutions.
Students in the UK can apply to only five universities per year.
US students can apply to up to 20 schools via the Common App.
33% of UC Berkeleys undergraduate class consists of transfer students from community colleges.
Jennifer Kohler studied at Wellesley College and the London School of Economics.
She completed leadership and career coaching training at Rice University.
One student spent a full year studying abroad at a university in France.
Her eldest daughter is CEO of an aerospace technology company and has three degrees.
Her daughter worked at NASA and SpaceX and helped land the Perseverance rover on Mars.
She recommends using YouTube and podcasts as starting points for exploring careers.
She advises students to write three pages about a topic before narrowing it to 500 words.
She has worked with students from multiple countries including Switzerland, France, and the Netherlands.
She notes that some European universities have a pass/fail system after the first year.
